results.title: Four centuries of growing pains
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Balla, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
The film traces the origins of the British Commonwealth through four hundred years of history. It reviews how countries like Canada, Australia, India, and other continental and island territories, came to be added, and how each developed to the point of self-government.

results.title: Road to independence
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Balla, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
There is world-wide significance in the planned process by which Britain is helping her colonies master the art of self-government. This concluding film cites recent developments in Ghana, Nigeria, Nyasaland and other colonial territories where political evolution has seen striking progress in recent years. Edgar McInnis analyzes these developments on the basis of two main considerations; and why a ruling power should arrange for its own departure from its colonies; why, once independent, the former subjects should continue to associate with their former master.

results.title: Child's play
results.creator_credit: Antonio Colacino, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Developing child”.
With the ability to walk, the child reaches a major milestone along the road to adulthood. One day they will leave their family’s care and face the world alone. The toddler asserts their new sense of independence. Suitable for teacher/tertiary level.

results.title: The Colonies look ahead
results.creator_credit: John Howe, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
A film survey of economic development, education and race relations in various British colonial territories. Progress in representative colonies, such as Kenya, is assessed on the basis of their ability to manage their own affairs and to achieve self-government. Narrated by Edgar McInnis.

results.title: Towards school
results.creator_credit: Antonio Colacino, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Developing child”
Preschool is, for the child, the gateway between the familiarity of home, and the formal education system. Shows children at play, developing and practising new skills.

results.title: Black and white in South Africa
results.creator_credit: Ronald Dick, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
South Africa, one of the largest members of the Commonwealth, a country with full self-government, has an acute race problem that causes dissension not only within its borders but within the Commonwealth and beyond. We see a country of fourteen million people where only one out of five is white. Edgar McInnis gives a dispassionate appraisal of the motivations behind the policy of apartheid and of whether the practice of segregation provides a satisfactory solution. This documentary provides a comprehensive overview of the history of South African colonisation, the apartheid system and the country’s political developments using re-enactments, drawings, interviews and historic footage. Narrated by Edgar McInnis.

results.title: Poverty and plenty
results.creator_credit: John Howe, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
The ancient greatness of he East must be preserved, say men like Nehru, “but the ancient evils must be eliminated.” This film concerns itself with the latter and shows how helping the Asiatic countries of the Commonwealth to attain higher living standards has become a challenge not only to the more privileged countries within the Commonwealth but to the nations outside. The Colombo Plan is the medium through which economic assistance is extended, and in this film we see some of the many practical forms it takes.

results.title: Algeria
results.creator_credit: James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “The Crossroads of the world: a study of North Africa and the Middle East”.
Indicative of the direction and strength of Muslim revolt against European colonisers was the struggle for Algerian independence. This film recapitulates Algeria’s history up to the signing of the French-Algerian agreement and the last-ditch stand of the secret, outlaw European army. Figures of the Algerian resistance emerge on the screen as the film follows the Algerian resistance army to their mountain stronghold and takes a look at the peace conferences in France. Narrated by James Beveridge. Edited by Dennis Sawyer.

results.title: Pregnancy and birth
results.creator_credit: Antonio Colacino, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Developing child”.
Derek Llewellyn-Jones, Professor of Obstetrics, University of Sydney, stresses the importance of prenatal care, child birth education and psychoprophylaxis in promoting relaxation and confidence during the birth process. An actual birth is shown.
